clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Probiotics on Exacerbation of Inflammatory Bowel Disease Exacerbation (Crohn's Disease)
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Probiotics on the Rate of Recovery of Inflammatory Bowel Disease Exacerbation (Crohn's Disease) and Markers of Inflammation

lead_sponsor.agency: The Baruch Padeh Medical Center, Poriya

clinical_study.source: The Baruch Padeh Medical Center, Poriya

brief_summary.textblock: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is an immune mediated chronic intestinal condition. It includes ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease(CD). probiotics have been shown to be effective in varried clinical conditions ranging fron infantile diarrhea, necrotizing enterocolitis,helicobacter pylori infections, etc.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective study that will enroll 50 patients with Crohn's disease.Each patient will get the study medication for 6 weeks and will be evaluated twice- before enrollment and after 6 weeks of treatment.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: to study the ability to create endothelial progenitor stem cells following probiotic management compared to placebo group

arm_group.description: To study the effect of probiotic on the ability to build endothelial progenitor stem cells and to study clinical recovery of patients with Crohn's Disease.
This will be the comparison group to the experimantal group that recives Probiotic.

intervention.description: Clinical evaluation according to the Crohn's activity scale

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients with Crohns' disease who are stable or have mild acute exacerbations that do not necessitate treatment with systemic corticosteroids
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnant women, under 18 years or over 60 years,
- patients with known ulcerative colitis,
- patients with any cancer,
- patients with heart failure

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: The Baruch Padeh Medical Center, Poriya

clinical_study.keyword: Crohn's disease, endothelial progenitor cells, probiotic
